justification: "Higher response thresholds mean that a person needs more evidence to trigger a response, and so, threshold settings represent how cautious a person is."
"The quality of evidence sampled from the stimulus governs the drift rate, which can be interpreted as the speed of information processing."
"Starting points and response thresholds can be different for different response options capturing any inherit biases people have."
"The time necessary for processes outside of evidence accumulation is the non-decision time, which includes the time needed for perceptual encoding and overtly executing a motor response."
construct: perceptual encoding and motor execution time
